Database on Alessandro Lacava /categories/database/ Recent content in Database on Alessandro Lacava Hugo en-us <<<<<<< HEAD Wed, 04 Jun 2008 13:33:24 +0000 ======= Wed, 04 Jun 2008 13:33:24 +0000 >>>>>>> origin/master Performance differences between IN and EXISTS /blog/performance-differences-between-in-and-exists/ Wed, 04 Jun 2008 13:33:24 +0000 /blog/performance-differences-between-in-and-exists/

Very often I hear people wondering if it’s better the EXISTS or the IN operator. Let’s start by saying that the two operators behave differently when NULL values are involved (see this post).

If you are sure that the field used to join the tables does not include NULL values then the IN operator “generally” performs better than EXISTS. I say “generally” because this is not always the case. For example consider the following query:

NOT IN vs. NOT EXISTS when NULL values are involved /blog/not-in-vs-not-exists-when-null-values-are-involved/ Wed, 04 Jun 2008 13:24:09 +0000 /blog/not-in-vs-not-exists-when-null-values-are-involved/ <<<<<<< HEAD

NOT IN does not behave as you would expect when NULL values are involved. Suppose you have the following tables:

CD_FIELD DS_FIELD
1 ALPHA
2 BETA
**TABLE_A**
CD_FIELD DS_FIELD
1 GAMMA
NULL DELTA
**TABLE_B**

Now try the following query:

   
SELECT *
FROM table_a a
WHERE a.cd_field NOT IN (SELECT b.cd_field FROM table_b b);

Does the previous query return any row? The answer is NO it doesn’t, even if there is a value (2) in table_a.cd_field which is not present in table_b.cd_field.

======= NOT IN does not behave as you would expect when NULL values are involved. Suppose you have the following tables: CD_FIELD DS_FIELD 1 ALPHA 2 BETA **TABLE_A** CD_FIELD DS_FIELD 1 GAMMA NULL DELTA **TABLE_B** Now try the following query: SELECT * FROM table_a a WHERE a.cd_field NOT IN (SELECT b.cd_field FROM table_b b); Does the previous query return any row? The answer is NO it doesn’t, even if there is a value (2) in table_a. >>>>>>> origin/master How to get the number of columns in a ResultSet in Java /blog/how-to-get-the-number-of-columns-in-a-resultset-in-java/ Wed, 12 Dec 2007 10:32:31 +0000 /blog/how-to-get-the-number-of-columns-in-a-resultset-in-java/ <<<<<<< HEAD

In Java it is possible to retrieve the number of columns of a ResultSet dinamically, thanks to the ResultSetMetaData class. Here’s an example:

   
// Here you get the conn object. E.g.:
// Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(...);

Statement st = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rs = st.executeQuery("SELECT * FROM your_table");
ResultSetMetaData rsmd = rs.getMetaData();
int numCols = rsmd.getColumnCount();
System.out.println("Number of columns in your_table: " + numCols);

The previous code retrieves and displays the number of columns of your_table.

======= In Java it is possible to retrieve the number of columns of a ResultSet dinamically, thanks to the ResultSetMetaData class. Here’s an example: // Here you get the conn object. E.g.: // Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(...); Statement st = conn.createStatement(); ResultSet rs = st.executeQuery("SELECT * FROM your_table"); ResultSetMetaData rsmd = rs.getMetaData(); int numCols = rsmd.getColumnCount(); System.out.println("Number of columns in your_table: " + numCols); The previous code retrieves and displays the number of columns of your_table. >>>>>>> origin/master
